Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Design and Discovery of Multimetallic Hetergeneous Catalysts for a Future Biorefining Industry

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
#1534260 / #1534269
Heyden, Andreas / Bond, Jesse Q.

The proposal utilizes statistical analysis to estimate uncertainties in both experimental data and theoretical calculations relating to catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of succinic acid (SUCC HDO) - an important reaction in the refining of biomass-derived chemicals to commercially valuable products. The experimental and computational methods employed - combined with statistical error analysis - provide a more accurate and powerful approach for identifying improved catalytic materials than possible by either experiments or theory alone. The approach is applicable to a broad range of catalytic applications, and could provide a blueprint for a new approach to the discovery and design of catalytic materials. The results of the study will be made available to the catalysis community via a website and software tool.

Specifically, the project involves preparation of well-defined and well-dispersed bimetallic clusters of tin (Sn) adsorbed on ruthenium (Ru), platinum (Pt) or rhodium (Rh) deposited on amorphous silica or carbon supports. The catalysts will be characterized in detail with respect to structure, composition, and surface acidity, and then evaluated in the SUCC HDO reaction. A multiscale strategy will be used for the computations based on DFT methods and techniques developed in the investigators' laboratory aimed at reducing uncertainties in the estimation of free energies. Uncertainties in both the experimental and computational analyses will be subjected to Bayesian statistical analysis. Refinements to both the experimental and computational methods will be made to minimize the uncertainties and obtain meaningful comparisons between theory and experiment.

The methodology employed in the study can potentially guide materials selection and catalyst design for many applications beyond the specific catalysts and reaction demonstrated here. Rigorous standards are set for both the experimental and computational work, that when combined with statistical analysis, provide confidence heretofore lacking in the certainty with which new catalytic materials can be predicted. The selected reaction is in biomass processing and not only demonstrates application of the methods to complicated systems, but suggests potential use of the methods in both aqueous and gas-phase reactions important to renewable resources and energy sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our central research objective is to establish a new, multidisciplinary research approach based on deep integration of computation, data informatics, and experimentation for the rapid design and discovery of novel, multimetallic heterogeneous catalysts with exceptional activity, selectivity, and stability in aqueous-phase, biorefining applications.  Multimetallic catalysts are attractive for biomass processing, but insightful design of such materials is hindered by a lack of knowledge regarding the structure and function of their complex active sites under aqueous-phase reaction conditions.  Our central hypothesis has been that doubling the speed and reducing the cost associated with discovery and design of such materials―as demanded by the White House ?Materials Genome Initiative for Global Competitiveness? ―requires (1) rapid, in silico screening of catalytic materials, (2) the ability to synthesize, characterize and evaluate catalysts that have and retain well-defined active sites, and (3) systematic procedures for correlation and reconciliation of computational insights with experimental observations.

To enable rapid in silico screening of catalytic materials, we have developed an iterative feedback procedure for systematically improving mean-field microkinetic models that consider lateral interactions, and that is based on DFT data and machine learning models. Regarding the machine learning models, we developed a stacked-Gaussian process model that considers uncertainties in adsorption energies when predicting transition state energies. A distinguishing feature of our machine learning research has been the focus on larger hydrocarbon species relevant for biomass conversion on metallic surfaces. Overall, we found that for catalyst screening of the hydrodeoxygenation of organic acids, non-linear machine learning models are superior to linear models. For machine learning models (linear or non-linear) to be practical for catalyst screening, their accuracy has to be on the order of 0.2 eV, and the energy of surface intermediates has to be predicted with higher accuracy than transition state energies.

As a model system, we considered carboxylic acid reduction, which is important in biomass upgrading. Noble metals, like Pt or Ru, are active for COOH reduction; however, they facilitate undesirable C-C scission pathways, namely decarbonylation and hydrogenolysis. They also suffer from product inhibition due to the formation of carbon monoxide via decarbonylation. We have demonstrated that Sn addition to Pt suppresses decarbonylation; mitigates CO positioning; enhances rates of hydrodeoxygenation; and improves the selectivity toward alcohols and aldehydes, which are the major targets of carboxylic acid reduction. To this end, we employed strong-electrostatic adsorption to synthesize bimetallic (PtxSny) catalysts, which affords reasonable control over Sn deposition onto Pt domains. Our work has also revealed the dynamic behavior of bimetallic catalysts under reaction conditions, which motivates future development of approaches for determining turnover rates that are representative of the catalyst surface as it exists under reaction conditions.

Finally, we developed uncertainty quantification procedures for integrating experimental data with computational models. Our approach is based on Bayesian statistics and model selection to identify the active sites and reaction mechanisms.

Six Ph.D., two M.S., and three undergraduate students have been educated through this project. Seven peer-reviewed journal papers have been published, and we anticipate publication of about ten more peer-reviewed papers.  Finally, research results have been integrated into core chemical engineering curricula and joint graduate and undergraduate electives as in-class case studies at UofSC and Syracuse University.
